message.content:
Research and design the optimal architecture for an Adobe Premiere Pro plugin (CEP/UXP). 

Focus on:
1. CEP vs UXP - which is better for this use case (audio processing, timeline manipulation)
2. Plugin panel structure and UI framework options (React, Vue, vanilla)
3. ExtendScript/JavaScript bridge for timeline manipulation
4. How to select clips, modify them, color code them, rename them
5. Communication with external backend APIs
6. Best practices for Premiere plugin development in 2025
7. Recommended folder structure for the plugin
8. Manifest.xml configuration requirements
9. Debugging and testing approaches

Output a comprehensive technical document with specific recommendations and folder structure.

Based on my search results, here's what I found about Adobe Premiere Pro CEP vs UXP plugin development:

## Current State (2025)

### UXP (Unified eXtensibility Platform)
The current plan is to officially release UXP extensibility, approaching 1:1 parity, this calendar year; perhaps even this summer. Placing trackItems into sequences has been in UXP for months.(no content)UXP provides a unified JavaScript engine that has direct access to both the Premiere APIs and the UXP Core APIs. This is a big advantage over the previous extensibility technology (CEP), where the communication between the extension logic and the host application happened through a bridge (CSInterface) that passed messages back and forth between the two runtimes.(no content)Premiere version (v25.6) determines which Premiere DOM APIs are available, while UXP version (v8.1) determines which UXP Core APIs are available. Each Premiere release integrates a specific UXP version. For example, Premiere v25.6 includes UXP v8.1.

### CEP (Common Extensibility Platform)
CEP 12 shipped with Photoshop 25.12, Premiere Pro 25.0, and After Effects 25.0.(no content)CEP Extensions are comprised of a JavaScript/HTML/CSS frontend built on Node.js + Chromium frontend (similar to NW.js) and an ExtendScript backend for interacting with the host application. UXP Plugins are also JavaScript/HTML/CSS based, however they are built on their own unique stack by Adobe which makes them far less resource heavy than CEP's Node.js + Chromium stack.

### Key Differences

CEP and UXP each have their pros and cons, but the important thing to note is that UXP is replacing CEP so tracking with UXP updates is very important for all Adobe 3rd party developers.(no content)Adobe has made it clear that there will be a few years of overlap where both UXP and CEP are supported, in order to give developers enough time to transition their tools.

### Migration Recommendations

All of your CEP panels will have to be migrated to UXP at some point in the future and the sooner you can test UXP, report bugs, and request features you'll need to migrate your tools, the more chance Adobe will be able to address these requests before the UXP main launch in Premiere Pro.(no content)Adobe's first goal is parity with what ExtendScript could already do. Applying effects works, and UXP plugins can make Undo groupings, instead of introducing a new Undo item with each API call.

### Official Resources

Sample UXP plugins are available at: https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples/tree/main and documentation at: https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/(no content)Use CEP for legacy applications or cross-application plugins. Use UXP for modern applications with advanced UI needs.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Adobe CEP ExtendScript Premiere Pro clip selection, color label, and rename API:

## Key Findings

### Label Color API Limitations
One can only change the label color of projectItems; there's no API to do so, for trackItems.(no content)There's an existing feature request (DVAPR-4217788) for this functionality.

### Working with Clips and Selection
The ExtendScript API allows you to get project view selection using `app.getProjectViewSelection(viewIDs[0])` for working with selected items in the project panel.(no content)You can modify clip parameters using components, for example: `app.project.activeSequence.videoTracks[0].clips[0].components[0].properties[0]`.

### Label Color for Sequence Clips
Extensions usability is limited by the Adobe Premiere API. Only items that have a source can be labeled, such as video, image, and sound layers. Also, "Display the project item name and label color for all instances" setting has to be enabled in the project for it to work.(no content)That results in both Item and Layer colors being the same - changing color in the timeline automatically changes the color in the Project Panel. The label colors are in synch for layers and items. And this is a huge limitation.

### Sample Code and Resources
The PProPanel sample project is exhaustive in its exercise of Premiere Pro's ExtendScript API. You can find it at the Adobe-CEP/Samples GitHub repository.

The PProPanel sample exercises Premiere Pro's ExtendScript API: https://github.com/Adobe-CEP/Samples/tree/master/PProPanel.

### Important Note on CEP Future
As of Premiere Pro 25.6, CEP extensions to Premiere Pro have been superseded by UXP Extensibility. If you are starting new development, start in UXP. CEP extensions continue to be supported; the plan is to support both CEP and UXP for a calendar year, after which they will remove support for CEP extensibility.

### Adding Effects (QE DOM)
To discover available methods, `qe.project.reflect.methods` will show you available tools. To find effect names, you can run `qe.project.getVideoEffectList` and `qe.project.getVideoTransitionList`.

### API Documentation
Objects available from ExtendScript are completely distinct from the CEP interface, which is JavaScript-based. CEP information is available at: https://github.com/Adobe-CEP/CEP-Resources/tree/master/CEP_9.x/Documentation

Links: [{"title":"The Premiere UXP API","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/"},{"title":"Building your first UXP plugin","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/plugins/"},{"title":"Solved: how to insertClip in UXP plugin - Adobe Product Community - 15097904","url":"https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-discussions/how-to-insertclip-in-uxp-plugin/td-p/15097904"},{"title":"Request for Timeline Editing API Support (Clip Tra... - Adobe Product Community - 15624626","url":"https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-ideas/request-for-timeline-editing-api-support-clip-track-movement-flattening/idc-p/15625115"},{"title":"Premiere and UXP","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/introduction/"},{"title":"Get started - UXP plugin","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/plugins/getting-started/"},{"title":"GitHub - AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples","url":"https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples"},{"title":"Offline Docs - Premiere Pro Scripting Guide","url":"https://ppro-scripting.docsforadobe.dev/print_page/"},{"title":"Essential Development Tools for UXP","url":"https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/introduction/essentials/dev-tools/"},{"title":"Solved: Premiere Pro Extensions - To UXP or not to UXP - Adobe Product Community - 11326933","url":"https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-discussions/premiere-pro-extensions-to-uxp-or-not-to-uxp/td-p/11326933"}]

Here are the search results for Adobe Premiere Pro UXP plugin timeline manipulation and audio processing in 2025:

## Overview of Adobe Premiere Pro UXP Plugins

UXP (Unified eXtensibility Platform) is an integration framework built into Premiere and other Adobe Creative Cloud applications. It is powered by a modern JavaScript engine and offers the ability to access many Premiere functions at a programmatic level.(no content)UXP is the current extensibility standard for Adobe Creative Cloud applications, supported by a constantly growing set of applications, including Premiere (version 25.6), Photoshop, and InDesign.

## Current Status and Requirements

UXP plugins are supported in Premiere v25.6 and later since UDT v2.2.(no content)To build UXP plugins, you need Premiere (v25.6) or later and UXP Developer Tool (v2.2) or later.(no content)As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP. ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so, through September 2026.

## Timeline Manipulation Capabilities

UXP in Premiere Pro is in beta and very very new so lots of APIs haven't been built yet.(no content)The 'premiere_api' UXP example plugin shows how to clone and remove track items.

However, there are significant limitations for timeline manipulation:

There is no current API method (DOM, QE, CEP, or UXP) that can move an existing clip vertically between tracks. Premiere Pro no longer includes a keyboard mappable command like Move Clip Up/Down Between Tracks, meaning even UI automation cannot rely on a universal shortcut.(no content)If you need a production panel today or in the near future, you're going to need to build it in CEP.

## Audio Processing Challenges

Based on community discussions, developers are trying to build plugins to simplify audio tracks after simplifying multicam sequences, but they are struggling to figure out what tools are available to manipulate clips on the timeline.(no content)Ideally the simplify sequence tool could do this but for whatever reason it only does the video.

## Getting Started with UXP Plugin Development

UXP is a JavaScript-based extensibility platform (ES6/ECMAScript 2015 compliant) that helps you automate, optimize, and extend the capabilities of your favorite Adobe Creative Cloud products. It represents a comprehensive solution that lets you use Web technologies to build new features and tools for Desktop applications.(no content)The UXP Developer Tool (UDT) simplifies the process of creating, loading, managing, and debugging plugins for Adobe's UXP-powered applications.

For the latest documentation and samples, the official resources are available at [developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/](https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/) and there's also a UXP forum at forums.creativeclouddeveloper.com for developer discussions.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Adobe Premiere Pro plugin external API communication and HTTP requests:

## Adobe Premiere Pro Plugin API Communication

### UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform) - The Modern Approach

As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP; Unified Extensibility Platform.(no content)You can build performant plugins with modern HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. UXP is the next generation of APIs, for Premiere v25.6 and beyond.(no content)UXP provides a unified JavaScript engine that has direct access to both the Premiere APIs and the UXP Core APIs. This is a big advantage over the previous extensibility technology (CEP), where the communication between the extension logic and the host application happened through a bridge (CSInterface) that passed messages back and forth between the two runtimes. With UXP, everything runs natively in the same environment, and you just need to require() the appropriate modules to access the APIs you need.

### Network Requests and Permissions

UXP provides practical examples for common tasks like filesystem operations, network requests, and styling.(no content)UXP offers file system, networking, shell execution, and core UXP functionality.(no content)Permission-based APIs need to be allow-listed in your plugin's manifest.json. For example, to use the file system or make network requests, you must declare the appropriate permissions.

### External HTTP Communication Options

**PremiereRemote (CEP-based):**
There are two ways to trigger PremiereRemote functionality from outside: Using HTTP requests or using WebSocket calls.(no content)Using the CEP extension mechanism, PremiereRemote provides a framework to trigger your own Premiere functionality from outside of Premiere, e.g., by using AutoHotkey. This is achieved by starting a local server inside of Premiere, allowing to trigger custom functionality using a local http request or with websockets.

**Pymiere (Python Integration):**
Pymiere sends the ExtendScript code to the Pymiere Link extension via the requests library using HTTP. The Pymiere Link extension is essentially a node.js server which receives the ExtendScript code and executes it within Premiere Pro. Where required, Pymiere Link will return data as a JSON encoded response back to Pymiere.

### Legacy ExtendScript Support

Premiere Pro's ExtendScript-based API allows for broad control of the entire application. ExtendScript can access and manipulate most project elements, including metadata, exporting and rendering options.(no content)ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so, through September 2026.

### Key Resources

- **UXP Documentation**: https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/
- **C++ SDK Guide**: https://ppro-plugins.docsforadobe.dev/
- **Scripting Guide**: https://ppro-scripting.docsforadobe.dev/
- **PremiereRemote**: https://github.com/sebinside/PremiereRemote
- **Pymiere**: https://github.com/qmasingarbe/pymiere

UXP provides practical examples for common tasks like filesystem operations, network requests, and styling.(no content)UXP offers file system, networking, shell execution, and core UXP functionality.(no content)Permission-based APIs need to be allow-listed in your plugin's manifest.json. For example, to use the file system or make network requests, you must declare the appropriate permissions.

### External HTTP Communication Options

**PremiereRemote (CEP-based):**
There are two ways to trigger PremiereRemote functionality from outside: Using HTTP requests or using WebSocket calls.(no content)Using the CEP extension mechanism, PremiereRemote provides a framework to trigger your own Premiere functionality from outside of Premiere, e.g., by using AutoHotkey. This is achieved by starting a local server inside of Premiere, allowing to trigger custom functionality using a local http request or with websockets.

**Pymiere (Python Integration):**
Pymiere sends the ExtendScript code to the Pymiere Link extension via the requests library using HTTP. The Pymiere Link extension is essentially a node.js server which receives the ExtendScript code and executes it within Premiere Pro. Where required, Pymiere Link will return data as a JSON encoded response back to Pymiere.

### Legacy ExtendScript Support

Premiere Pro's ExtendScript-based API allows for broad control of the entire application. ExtendScript can access and manipulate most project elements, including metadata, exporting and rendering options.(no content)ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so, through September 2026.

### Key Resources

- **UXP Documentation**: https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/
- **C++ SDK Guide**: https://ppro-plugins.docsforadobe.dev/
- **Scripting Guide**: https://ppro-scripting.docsforadobe.dev/
- **PremiereRemote**: https://github.com/sebinside/PremiereRemote
- **Pymiere**: https://github.com/qmasingarbe/pymiere

Here's what I found about Adobe CEP Premiere Pro manifest.xml CSXS configuration:

## Adobe CEP Extension Configuration for Premiere Pro

### Project Structure
You must include a /CSXS/manifest.xml at the root of your project for Adobe apps to register your extension.(no content)The "CSXS" folder contains the information that is required to make the extension work within the Adobe application.(no content)Except for the required CSXS folder, which must contain manifest.xml, the folder structure is flexible. One recommended way to structure the folders would be: /CSXS -- contains the manifest.xml file, which stores the extension configuration data. As noted above, this is a requirement for your extension to show up in the host app.

### Key manifest.xml Elements
For a minimal setup, the key XML elements include: ExtensionBundleId (a unique bundle ID like com.my.test), Extension Id (a unique ID following syntax like ExtensionBundleID + .panel), and Host Name & Version (list of host application IDs and versions that your extension supports).

### Extension Types
These extension types are supported by CEP. You need to specify an extension's type in its manifest.xml.

- The Panel type behaves like any other application panel. It can be docked, participates in workspaces, has fly-out menus, and is re-opened at start-up if open at shutdown.
- A Modal Dialog type opens a new extension window and forces the user to interact only with the extension window before returning control to the host application. User can interact with host application only after closing extension window.
- A Modeless Dialog type opens a new extension window but doesn't force the user to interact with the extension window.

### Modifying Host Application Versions
Although these extensions are initially setup for a particular version of CEP, you can adjust the product version targeted by modifying the range inside the HostList element of the CSXS/manifest.xml file.

### Important Configuration Notes
Even if you are making an invisible extension (like a server or background process), you still need to provide a geometry and size attribute in your manifest. Your extension will not load if it doesn't have a size attribute, even if it is not rendering anything.(no content)If you want your extension to open its window when the host app launches, include the `<AutoVisible>true</AutoVisible>` setting in your manifest.

### Debugging Unsigned Extensions
Since Premiere only accepts signed extension, you should tell it to accept unsigned extensions. You might need to potentially cover 5 to 8 depending on which CSXS version you have, using commands like `defaults write com.adobe.CSXS.8 PlayerDebugMode 1`.(no content)If you are in the midst of development and want to bypass the need to sign your extensions, you can bypass the check for extension signatures by editing the CSXS preference properties file, located at: Win: regedit > HKEY_CURRENT_USER/Software/Adobe/CSXS.12, then add a new entry.

### Resources
The official documentation and samples are available in the Adobe-CEP GitHub repositories:
- [Adobe-CEP/Samples](https://github.com/Adobe-CEP/Samples) - Code samples including PProPanel for Premiere Pro
- [Adobe-CEP/Getting-Started-guides](https://github.com/Adobe-CEP/Getting-Started-guides) - Getting started guides
- [Adobe-CEP/CEP-Resources](https://github.com/Adobe-CEP/CEP-Resources) - Documentation including CEP 12 HTML Extension Cookbook


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, here's the information about Adobe Premiere Pro UXP manifest.json plugin structure and folder organization:

## Adobe Premiere Pro UXP Plugin Structure

### Manifest.json Overview

The Manifest file is a JSON file located at the root of the plugin bundle that contains metadata about the plugin. Each UXP plugin must have one manifest.json file that the host application uses to load and manage the plugin.(no content)In addition to core metadata such as the plugin's name, version, icons, and entry points, the manifest specifies permissions, compatibility details, and other definitions that shape how the plugin integrates with the host environment. Most importantly, it contains your plugin ID, which uniquely identifies your plugin when it's installed in the host application.

### Manifest Version

The manifest schema version indicates the version of the manifest schema. Premiere supports version "5".

### Key Manifest Properties

- **Plugin ID**: Uniquely identifies a plugin and is used to disambiguate plugin contexts, storage, errors, etc. For plugins distributed through the plugin marketplace, the id has to match the one set in the Developer Distribution portal.

- **Entry Points**: The array defines the entrypoints that the plugin provides; currently, only Commands and Panels are supported.

- **Main File**: The primary JavaScript or HTML file is relative to the plugin's installation directory. It supports HTML and JS files, such as index.html and index.js. If not specified, main.js is used.

- **Icons**: An array of icons representing the overall plugin or panel icon. The host application uses these icons to present the plugin to the user. If the icons array is missing, a default icon will be used.

### Icon Specifications

Icon definitions include the width and height of the icon in pixels, and the path to the icon, relative to the plugin's installation directory. Supports PNG (.png), JPG (.jpg or .jpeg), and SVG (.svg) files. You can also specify the scaling factors that the icon supports.

### Permissions

To ensure that plugins are secure, UXP requires that plugins declare the permissions they need to function. Permissions not explicitly declared will be denied by default.

### Development Requirements

To develop UXP plugins, you need Premiere (v25.6) or later and UXP Developer Tool (v2.2) or later.(no content)Premiere's Developer Mode should be enabled. Open the Settings menu, select the Plugins tab and select the Enable developer mode checkbox. You will need to restart Premiere for the changes to take effect.

### Plugin Folder Structure

The UXP Developer Tool will create a new folder with the name you specified in the location you specified. The folder will contain the plugin files including the manifest.json, index.html, and other necessary files.

### Reloading Changes

If you make any changes to the manifest.json file, you must manually unload and reload the plugin. In the UXP Developer Tool, in the row for your plugin, click Unload and then Load & Watch once more.

### Hybrid Plugins

Addon definitions exist for hybrid plugins. A UXP Hybrid plugin is a UXP plugin that can access the power of C++ native libraries. However, Premiere doesn't support hybrid plugins yet.

### Current Status (2025)

As of August 2025, only Premiere Pro BETA builds support UXP plugins. The Premiere Pro UXP API documentation is available at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/.

# Premiere Pro CEP Extension Manifest Structure

## Extension Configuration
The manifest defines a Premiere Pro sample panel with **ExtensionBundleId** "com.adobe.PProPanel" and **ExtensionBundleVersion** "11.1". The individual extension carries **Version** "10.3.0".

## Host & Runtime Requirements
- **Host**: PPRO (Premiere Pro) Version 9.0 or higher
- **CSXS Runtime**: Version 6.0 required
- **Locale**: All locales supported

## Resource Paths
The extension specifies three critical resources:
- **MainPath**: "./index.html" (UI interface)
- **ScriptPath**: "./PProPanel.jsx" (ExtendScript logic)
- **CEFCommandLine Parameters**: "--allow-file-access", "--allow-file-access-from-files", "--allow-running-insecure-content"

## Lifecycle & UI Settings
- **AutoVisible**: true (panel displays automatically)
- **UI Type**: Panel
- **Menu Label**: "PProPanel (SDK sample panel)"
- **Default Dimensions**: 180px width × 300px height

The manifest demonstrates standard CEP 6.0 architecture for Premiere Pro extensions, integrating HTML5 UI with ExtendScript backend processing.

Here's what I found about Adobe Premiere Pro UXP debugging with the UXP Developer Tool and Chrome DevTools in 2025:

## UXP Developer Tool (UDT) Overview

The UXP Developer Tool (UDT) simplifies the process of creating, loading, managing, and debugging plugins for Adobe's UXP-powered applications.(no content)UXP plugins are supported in Premiere Pro v25.6 and later since UDT v2.2.

## Debugging with Chrome DevTools

One of the easiest ways to debug these technologies is by using the Chrome Debug Tool. Adobe uses the same within UDT, which stands for the UXP Developer Tool.(no content)A high-level understanding of Chrome DevTools will be very useful. Developers should familiarize themselves with accessing DOM, modifying CSS, and debugging JavaScript by adding breakpoints.(no content)Although UDT -> Debug lets you set breakpoints and debug your code using Chrome Debug Tool, there are additional debugging techniques available as well.

## UXP Devtools CLI Features

UXP Devtools provides the ability to discover UXP-compatible Adobe apps, load development plugins in a target app (no symlinks or deep file system spelunking required), reload your currently running plugin instance with new changes (no app restart required), and launch a rich DevTools environment for debugging your plugin.

## Known Issues in 2025

Several developers have reported connection issues with the UXP Developer Tool:

Users have experienced critical issues with the UXP development environment on Premiere Pro 25.3 that prevents loading any UXP extension, including basic starter templates. The UXP Developer Tool consistently fails with the error: "No applications are connected to the service."(no content)When launching the UXP Developer Tool, some users report that the "Select an Application" dropdown only shows "Premiere Pro Beta," and it does not detect current, stable installations of Premiere Pro 2025.(no content)As of August 2025, only Premiere Pro BETA builds support UXP plugins.

## Setup Requirements

Developers need to install the Adobe UXP Developer Tool (UDT v2.2 or later), enable Developer Mode in both UDT and Premiere, and scaffold their first plugin.(no content)The UXP Developer Tool requires administrator-level privileges to run correctly.(no content)The left panel shows the currently opened Creative Cloud desktop applications that support UXP and are "connected" to UDT. Plugins can only be loaded when the application is running; as soon as you launch it, the Connected Apps section will populate.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about the Adobe Premiere Pro ExtendScript API for trackItem clip setColorLabel and name properties:

## Key Findings

### setColorLabel API for trackItems

One can only change the label color of projectItems; there's no API to do so, for trackItems.(no content)There's an existing feature request for this functionality (DVAPR-4217788).

### getColorLabel() / setColorLabel() for projectItems

For projectItems, you can use getColorLabel() / setColorLabel().(no content)Note: trackItems created from a projectItem will not have their label color updated; any new trackItems created from those projectItems will get the updated label.

### TrackItem Object Properties

The TrackItem object represents an item on a video or audio track, within a Sequence object.

The TrackItem has various properties including:
- Components associated with the trackItem, which can include intrinsic transformations, as well as video and audio effects.
- Duration of the trackItem (Time object, read-only).
- End time - the visible end time of the trackItem in the sequence, relative to the beginning of its corresponding sequence.

### trackItem.name Property

The trackItem has a `name` property that can be accessed, as shown in sample code: `trackItem.name`

### ExtendScript API Status

As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform).(no content)ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so, through September 2026.(no content)No further changes or improvements to Premiere Pro's ExtendScript API are planned or scheduled.(no content)Any such changes will be reconsidered once Premiere Pro moves to UXP-based extensibility.

### Resources

The official documentation for Premiere Pro's ExtendScript API is available at: https://ppro-scripting.docsforadobe.dev

Based on my search, here's what I found about Adobe Premiere Pro UXP React framework UI panel development in 2025:

## Overview of UXP for Premiere Pro

UXP (Unified eXtensibility Platform) is an integration framework built into Premiere and other Adobe Creative Cloud applications. It is powered by a modern JavaScript engine and offers the ability to access many Premiere functions at a programmatic level. With UXP, you can build unique tools that integrate with and optimize the most precise, demanding workflows. These tools reduce repetition, maximize efficiency, and transform Premiere into a bespoke application tailored to the needs of any project.(no content)UXP is the current extensibility standard for Adobe Creative Cloud applications, supported by a constantly growing set of applications, including Premiere (version 25.6), Photoshop, and InDesign.

## Current Status

UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform) is now available for development in Premiere Pro Beta. This marks a significant milestone in Adobe's journey to modernize and enhance the extensibility framework for third-party developers.(no content)As of August 2025, only Premiere Pro BETA builds support UXP plugins. The Premiere Pro UXP API documentation is available at developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/. You need a Premiere Pro BETA build, available through Creative Cloud Desktop.

## React Development with UXP

There's a lot of config required to get React working in UXP. Bolt UXP makes this easy and is free & open source.(no content)Developers have reported getting React apps working with React version 16, with questions about whether newer React versions like 18 will be supported.

### Bolt UXP - A Key Tool for React Development

Bolt UXP is a lightning-fast boilerplate for building Adobe UXP Plugins in Svelte, React, or Vue built on Vite + TypeScript + Sass.(no content)Bolt UXP is 100% free and open source, being released under the MIT license with no attribution required. This means you are free to use it in your free or commercial projects.(no content)There's also a Webview UI option available. If you are new to UXP, it's recommended to leave the Webview option disabled as it adds to the complexity of your project. Enabling the Webview UI option allows you to build your User Interface with full CSS/HTML/JS DOM support following Edge on Windows and Safari on MacOS.

## Getting Started

To build your first UXP plugin, you will learn to scaffold one from an existing template, customize it, and run it in Premiere. You need Premiere (v25.6) or later and UXP Developer Tool (v2.2) or later.(no content)Premiere's Developer Mode should be enabled. Open the Settings menu, select the Plugins tab and select the Enable developer mode checkbox. You will need to restart Premiere for the changes to take effect.(no content)When building UXP plugins for Premiere, you don't need to start from scratch. Adobe provides Samples (complete, working examples that demonstrate specific features or use cases) and Starters (minimal templates with framework setup to help you begin a new plugin project).

## Key Resources

- **Official Documentation**: [developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/](https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/)
- **Bolt UXP (React/Vue/Svelte boilerplate)**: [github.com/hyperbrew/bolt-uxp](https://github.com/hyperbrew/bolt-uxp)
- **Sample Code Repository**: [github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples](https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples)

content.content:
# Bolt UXP: Project Structure & Setup Overview

## Project Architecture

Bolt UXP organizes its codebase into several key directories:

- **`src/`** - Main UXP plugin logic and backend code
- **`webview-ui/`** - Optional separate frontend context (Beta feature)
- **`vite-uxp-plugin/`** - Custom Vite plugin for UXP compilation
- **`public/`**, **`public-hybrid/`**, **`public-zip/`** - Asset directories
- **`scripts/`** - Build and deployment automation
- **`.github/`** - GitHub Actions workflows

## Supported Frameworks

The boilerplate supports three modern JavaScript frameworks:

1. **React** - Via configuration file `package.react.jsonc`
2. **Vue** - Via configuration file `package.vue.jsonc`
3. **Svelte** - Via configuration file `package.svelte.jsonc`

Developers select their preferred framework during initial project creation.

## Build Configuration

The project leverages Vite as its build engine with TypeScript and SCSS support. Configuration files include:

- **`vite.config.ts`** - Primary bundler settings
- **`uxp.config.ts`** - UXP-specific plugin parameters
- **`tsconfig.json`** (variant files per framework) - TypeScript compilation rules

## Setup Instructions

Create a new project using your package manager:

```
yarn create bolt-uxp
npx create-bolt-uxp
pnpm create bolt-uxp
```

The creator tool "guides developers through CLI prompts" to configure their plugin framework, host applications (Photoshop, InDesign, Premiere Pro), and optional features.

### Core Development Workflow

1. **Install dependencies**: `yarn`, `npm i`, or `pnpm i`
2. **Build assets**: `yarn build` (must precede development)
3. **Hot reload development**: `yarn dev` (integrates with Adobe UXP Developer Tool)

## Key Features

- Lightning-fast hot module reloading during development
- "TypeScript Definitions for UXP and Photoshop APIs"
- Multi-host application support with unified codebase
- Optional webview UI context for full CSS/HTML/JS capabilities
- Hybrid C++ plugin support (Photoshop only)
- GitHub Actions-ready CCX release pipeline
- MIT licensing with no attribution requirements

content.content:
# TrackItem Object - Properties and Methods

## Properties (Attributes)

1. **components** - ComponentCollection object (read-only); "components associated with this trackItem. This can include intrinsic transformations, as well as video and audio effects."

2. **duration** - Time object (read-only); duration of the trackItem

3. **end** - Time object (read/write); "visible end time of the trackItem in the sequence, relative to the beginning of its corresponding sequence"

4. **inPoint** - Time object (read/write); "in point set on the source for this trackItem instance, relative to the beginning of the source"

5. **outPoint** - Time object (read/write); "out point set on the source for this TrackItem instance, relative to the beginning of the source"

6. **start** - Time object (read/write); "visible start time of the trackItem in the sequence, relative to the beginning of its corresponding sequence"

7. **name** - String (read/write); name of the track item

8. **type** - Number (read-only); "Number, `1` means video, `2` means audio"

9. **mediaType** - String (read-only); either "Audio" or "Video"

10. **matchName** - String (read-only); match name identifier

11. **nodeId** - String; node identifier

12. **projectItem** - ProjectItem object; source media reference

13. **disabled** - Boolean (read/write); disabled state of the TrackItem

## Methods

- getSpeed() - returns speed multiplier
- isAdjustmentLayer() - returns boolean
- isSpeedReversed() - returns 1 or 0
- isSelected() - returns boolean
- setSelected(state, updateUI) - sets selection state
- getMatchName() - returns match name string
- remove(inRipple, inAlignToVideo) - removes track item
- move(newInPoint) - shifts track item position
- getMGTComponent() - adds Motion Graphics Template

content.content:
# ProjectItem Object - Properties and Methods

## Properties (Attributes)

| Property | Type | Access | Description |
|----------|------|--------|-------------|
| **name** | String | Read/Write | "The name of the project item" |
| **children** | ProjectItemCollection | Read-only | Array of items contained within the project item |
| **type** | Enumerated | Read-only | One of: "CLIP", "BIN", "ROOT", "FILE" |
| **treePath** | String | Read-only | Current project location (e.g., `\\ProjectName.prproj\\Media\\...`) |
| **nodeId** | String | Read-only | "A unique ID assigned to the project item, upon its addition" |
| **teamProjectsAssetId** | String | Read-only | Team Projects Asset ID identifier |
| **getAudioChannelMapping** | AudioChannelMapping | Read-only | Audio channel mapping applied to item |
| **getOverrideColorSpaceList** | Object | Read-only | Available color space override options |

## Key Methods

**Metadata & Color:**
- `getColorLabel()`, `setColorLabel(labelColor)`
- `getColorSpace()`, `getOriginalColorSpace()`
- `getProjectMetadata()`, `setProjectMetadata()`
- `getXMPMetadata()`, `setXMPMetadata()`
- `getProjectColumnsMetadata()`

**Media Management:**
- `getMediaPath()`, `changeMediaPath(newPath)`
- `canChangeMediaPath()`, `canProxy()`, `hasProxy()`
- `attachProxy()`, `getProxyPath()`
- `refreshMedia()`, `isOffline()`, `setOffline()`

**In/Out Points:**
- `getInPoint()`, `setInPoint()`, `clearInPoint()`
- `getOutPoint()`, `setOutPoint()`, `clearOutPoint()`
- `setStartTime()`, `startTime()`

**Bins & Organization:**
- `createBin(name)`, `createSmartBin()`, `deleteBin()`, `renameBin()`
- `moveBin()`, `select()`

**Clip Operations:**
- `createSubClip()`, `isMergedClip()`, `isMulticamClip()`, `isSequence()`
- `getFootageInterpretation()`, `setFootageInterpretation()`
- `setOverrideFrameRate()`, `setOverridePixelAspectRatio()`

**Additional:**
- `getMarkers()`, `videoComponents()`, `getEmbeddedLUTID()`, `getInputLUTID()`
- `findItemsMatchingMediaPath()`

Based on my search, here's the relevant information about Adobe Premiere Pro UXP API for trackItem, sequence, and clip manipulation in 2025:

## Overview

As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform).(no content)ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so, through September 2026.

## UXP API Documentation

UXP (Unified eXtensibility Platform) is an integration framework built into Premiere and other Adobe Creative Cloud applications. It is powered by a modern JavaScript engine and offers the ability to access many Premiere functions at a programmatic level.

### Accessing the Premiere DOM

The following line allows you access to the Premiere DOM via UXP. From here, you can open documents, modify them, run menu items, and more.(no content)An important difference between ExtendScript (and CEP) and UXP in Premiere is that all ExtendScript calls to Premiere were synchronous, meaning they blocked the Premiere UI while executing. In UXP, a method call is asynchronous, and does not block the UI thread.

### Available APIs for Clip/Sequence Manipulation

These APIs let you, among other things, to: Access and modify projects — sequences, tracks, clips, and markers; Work with media — import files, manage project items; Control playback — set in/out points, control the playhead.

### TrackItem Object

The TrackItem object represents an item on a video or audio track, within a Sequence object.

Key properties include:
- The duration of the trackItem. Time object, read-only.
- The visible end time of the trackItem in the sequence, relative to the beginning of its corresponding sequence (NOT the sequence zero point). This may differ from the trackItem's out point, which is relative to the source. Time object, read/write.
- The visible start time of the trackItem in the sequence, relative to the beginning of its corresponding sequence (NOT the sequence zero point). This may differ from the trackItem's in point, which is relative to the source. Time object, read/write.

### VideoClipTrackItem Class

Create add transition action for sequence. Returns an action that moves the inPoint of the track item to a new time, by shifting it by a number of seconds.

### Sequence Class

The Sequence class includes TrackItemSelection which returns the current selection group of the sequence. It also provides methods to get video/audio time display format, sequence settings, time base, video track from track index, and video track count.

### Version Information

Premiere version (v25.6) determines which Premiere DOM APIs are available. UXP version (v8.1) determines which UXP Core APIs are available. Each Premiere release integrates a specific UXP version. For example, Premiere v25.6 includes UXP v8.1.

### Moving Clips Between Tracks - Limitations

There is no current API method (DOM, QE, CEP, or UXP) that can move an existing clip vertically between tracks.(no content)The 'premiere_api' UXP example plugin, the right starting point for any future integrations, shows how to clone and remove track items.

## Resources

- **Official Documentation**: The Premiere Pro UXP API documentation is available at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/.
- **Sample Plugins**: Available on GitHub at AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples
- **Developer Forums**: For UXP-related discussions, the UXP forum is available at https://forums.creativeclouddeveloper.com/c/uxp-for-premiere-pro/105

Based on my search results, here's what I found about Adobe UXP plugin network permissions and using the fetch API for external backend communication:

## Network Permissions in Adobe UXP Plugins

To ensure that plugins are secure, UXP requires that plugins declare the permissions they need to function.

### Manifest Configuration

In plugins, you should seek permission for access in the manifest and specify the domains of the endpoints.(no content)The manifest specifies the domains that the plugin can access in network requests. You can also allow access to all domains by setting domains to "all".

### Using the Fetch API

In order to leverage `fetch`, update the `manifest.json` with the `network.domains` permission. From UXP v7.4.0 onwards `permissions.network.domains` does not support WildCards in top-level domains.(no content)Network APIs are accessed just as in a browser, via the global classes XMLHttpRequest and WebSocket, and the global function fetch(). These are similar to the web standard XHR, fetch, and WebSocket found in browsers.

### Common Issues and Solutions

**Manifest Version Matters:**
After testing with manifest v5, some developers found fetch is no longer working (it was working correctly with version 4). The error message states: "Plugin is not permitted to access the network apis. A valid domains entry is required in requiredPermissions.network field of the manifest."

**IP Addresses vs Domain Names:**
When trying to connect to internal servers, using the domain name instead of the IP address resolves the issue. IP addresses are not allowed with the UXP data transfers.

**requiredPermissions vs permissions:**
requiredPermissions needs domains under network. Sites works under permissions but UXP wants a requiredPermissions and not a permissions.

### Permission-Based APIs

Permission-based APIs need to be allow-listed in your plugin's manifest.json. For example, to use the file system or make network requests, you must declare the appropriate permissions.

### User Consent Considerations

Make sure you configure the most accurate permission for your use case because in the future Adobe will ask users to provide their consent based on it. For example, for file operations, you may find 'fullAccess' to be the least restrictive and hence the easiest to pick, but a user may not be comfortable giving full access to their system unless it's absolutely necessary and might deny the installation of your plugin altogether.

### HTTPS Requirement

There are two things that caught developers by surprise in the fetch API: only HTTPS is supported (which is unfortunate for any localhost usage), and the request is cached.

Here are the search results for "Adobe CEP Premiere Pro best practices 2024 2025 architecture folder structure":

## Adobe CEP and Premiere Pro Best Practices

### CEP Extension Loading Architecture

CEP first searches the product extension folder, then the system extension folder, and finally per-user extension folder.(no content)Extensions without an appropriate host application ID and version are filtered out.

When resolving conflicts between extensions:
- If two extensions have same extension bundle ID, the one with higher version is loaded.
- If two extensions have same extension bundle ID and same version, the one whose manifest file has latest modification date is loaded.
- If two extensions have same extension bundle ID, same version and same manifest modification date, CEP loads the first one that is found.(no content)However, if an extension load FAILS due to any issue such as a Signature Verification error, then it stops trying to load that extension altogether.

### CEP Development Resources

Adobe provides Getting Started guides and samples for CEP extensions on GitHub (Adobe-CEP/Getting-Started-guides).

### Premiere Pro Production Folder Structure Best Practices

Premiere Pro expects to have full control over what is placed in the production folder, so you should never put any other files inside the production folder.(no content)Think of the production folder as analogous to the .prproj file. When you're organizing stuff out on disk, in Finder or Explorer, treat the Production folder like one single unit, like your project file would be.(no content)One of the most powerful uses of a production is to have it in a shared network location, and then have multiple editors working inside it at the same time. For that to work, it has to be a folder so multiple editors can open the projects inside.

### Project Panel Organization

The Project panel lets you use bins that help you organize project content the same way as folders in Windows Explorer or macOS Finder. Bins can contain source files, sequences, and other bins. As your project grows, you can make new bins to contain those items.

Best practices for bins include:
- Store main sequences and backup sequences, and organize files by type, such as video, still images, and audio files.(no content)If you're working with a project in Premiere, you organize in the Project panel by creating bins—X media in one, Y media in another, graphics in a third, audio in a fourth. Sequences in their own bin.(no content)Working with multiple projects open, and grabbing things from one to use in another, leads to many messy problems. So use bins in one project.

### Project Templates

Video production can be complex. The way to manage that – and scale your projects – is to set up your workflow before you begin. Using Premiere Pro projects as templates allows you to do that.

### Folder Sync Tools

There's a great add-on called Watchtower ($40) that automatically syncs project bins with system folders for those who want automatic synchronization between filesystem folders and Premiere Pro bins.
